com.apriori.collections

Class Iterables

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.collections.Iterables

  • public final class Iterables
extends Object
    Utility methods for working with instances of Iterable and Iterator.

    • Method Detail

      • asCollection

        public static <E> Collection<E> asCollection(Iterable<E> iter)
        Returns a view of the given iterable as a collection. If the given iterable already implements Collection then it is returned. Otherwise, an unmodifiable collection view is returned. The return view may require linear time to compute the size (by actually performing an iteration and counting elements).
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the collection
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        Returns:
        a view of the given iterable as a collection

      • comparator

        public static <E> Comparator<Iterable<E>> comparator(Comparator<? super E> comparator)
        Returns a comparator of iterables based on the given comparator of elements. The returned comparator will order iterables in pseudo-lexical order, as if each element were a character in a string. So it first compares the first element from two iterables. If those are equal then it must compare the next elements and so on. If the end of one iterable is encountered first, then the shorter one (which is a strict prefix of the longer one) is considered less than the longer one.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of element being compared
        Parameters:
        comparator - a comparator of elements
        Returns:
        a corresponding comparator of iterables

      • addTo

        public static <E> boolean addTo(Iterator<E> iter,
                                Collection<? super E> coll)
        Adds the elements from the given iterator to the given collection. On return, the iterator will have been exhausted and Iterator.hasNext() will return false.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements retrieved from the given iterator
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterator
        coll - a collection
        Returns:
        true if the collection was modified; false if the iterator yielded no elements or if the collection was not modified by the additions (e.g. Collection.add(Object) returns false for all elements)
        See Also:
        addTo(Iterable, Collection)

      • addTo

        public static <E> boolean addTo(Iterable<E> iter,
                                Collection<? super E> coll)
        Adds the elements from the given iterable to the given collection.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the given iterable
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        coll - a collection
        Returns:
        true if the collection was modified; false if the iterable contained no elements or if the collection was not modified by the additions (e.g. Collection.add(Object) returns false for all elements)
        See Also:
        addTo(Iterator, Collection)

      • contains

                               Object o)
        Returns true if the given iterable contains the given object.
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        o - an object
        Returns:
        true if the given object was found in the given iterable
        See Also:

      • contains

        public static boolean contains(Iterator<?> iter,
                               Object o)
        Returns true if the given iterator contains the given object. On return, the iterator will have been exhausted and Iterator.hasNext() will return false.
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterator
        o - an object
        Returns:
        true if the given object was found in the given iterator
        See Also:
        Collection.contains(Object), contains(Iterable, Object)

      • singletonIterator

        public static <E> Iterator<E> singletonIterator(E element)
        Returns an iterator that yields the given single element and then no more. An attempt to remove the element using the iterator's remove method will throw UnsupportedOperationException.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of the element
        Parameters:
        element - an element
        Returns:
        an iterator that yields only the one element

      • singletonIterator

        public static <E> Iterator<E> singletonIterator(E element,
                                                Runnable onRemove)
        Returns an iterator that yields the given single element and then no more. An attempt to remove the element using the iterator's remove method will invoke the given removal handler.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of the element
        Parameters:
        element - an element
        onRemove - a removal handler, invoked when the iterator's remove method is called
        Returns:
        an iterator that yields only the one element

      • unique

        public static <E> Iterator<E> unique(Iterator<E> iter)
        Returns an iterator that omits duplicates from the given iterator. Note that the tracking of duplicates requires state that can use O(n) amount of memory.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements retrieved from the iterator
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterator
        Returns:
        an iterator that returns the items of the given iterator but omits duplicates

      • unique

        public static <E> Iterable<E> unique(Iterable<E> iter)
        Returns an iterable that omits duplicates from the given iterable. Note that the tracking of duplicates requires state that can use O(n) amount of memory for each iteration.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the iterable
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        Returns:
        an iterable that returns the items of the given iterable but omits duplicates

      • reversed

        public static <E> Iterator<E> reversed(Iterable<E> iterable)
        Returns an iterator that navigates over the given iterable in reverse order. Most iterables do not provide an efficient way to do this, in which case a stack is used (and thus will require O(n) amount of memory). But for those that do provide efficient implementations (like lists, deques, and navigable sets) they will be used so there is no space overhead.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the iterable
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        an iterator that visits the elements of the iterable in reverse order

      • trySize

        public static OptionalInt trySize(Iterable<?> iterable)
        Queries for the size of the given iterable, if known. If the given iterable implements Collection or SizedIterable then the size is returned. Otherwise, an absent value is returned, indicating that the size is not known.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        the size of the given iterable if known
        See Also:
        size(Iterable)

      • size

        public static int size(Iterable<?> iterable)
        Queries for the size of the given iterable, iterating and counting if necessary. If the given iterable implements Collection or SizedIterable then its size method is interrogated. Otherwise, an iteration is made and the elements are counted.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        the size of the given iterable
        See Also:
        trySize(Iterable), size(Iterator)

      • size

        public static int size(Iterator<?> iterator)
        Counts the number of elements in the given iterator. On return, the iterator will have been exhausted and Iterator.hasNext() will return false.
        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        Returns:
        the size of the given iterator
        See Also:
        size(Iterable)

      • snapshot

        public static <E> Collection<E> snapshot(Iterable<? extends E> iterable)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable. This involves iterating over the elements and creating an unmodifiable collection with all of its contents.

        The snapshot is created with as little overhead as possible using a strategy like used by ArrayList, except using linked nodes of arrays (each larger than the previous) instead of resizing a single array (so no copies need be made when the initial array gets full). The initial array is sized based on the given iterable's trySize(Iterable) size or 16 if the size is unknown.

        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an unmodifiable collection
        See Also:
        snapshot(Iterator)

      • snapshot

        public static <E> Collection<E> snapshot(Iterator<? extends E> iterator)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterator. This involves exhausting the elements and creating an unmodifiable collection with all of its contents. On return, the iterator will have been exhausted and Iterator.hasNext() will return false.

        The snapshot is created with as little overhead as possible using a strategy like used by ArrayList, except using linked nodes of arrays (each larger than the previous) instead of resizing a single array (so no copies need be made when the initial array gets full). The initial array is sized based on the given iterable's trySize(Iterable) size or 16 if the size is unknown.

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterator's contents in an unmodifiable collection
        See Also:
        snapshot(Iterable)

      • toArray

        public static Object[] toArray(Iterable<?> iterable)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable as an array. Implementations that already have a toArray method, like Collection and ImmutableCollection, will just use that existing implementation.

        Iterables that do not provide such a method must resort to a custom mechanism. A snapshot of the iterable is captured, and then a new array is created from the contents of that snapshot. So there is O(n) memory overhead, in addition to the O(n) memory needed by the returned array.

        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(), toArray(Iterator), toArray(Iterable, Object[])

      • toArray

        public static <T> T[] toArray(Iterable<?> iterable,
                              T[] array)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable as an array of the given type. The given array is used if it is large enough. If it is too large, a null terminator will be written to the location after the end of the given iterable's contents. If it is too small, a new array with the same component type will be allocated and returned.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        array - an array
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(Object[]), toArray(Iterator, Object[]), toArray(Iterable)

      • toArray

        public static Object[] toArray(Iterator<?> iter)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterator as an array.

        A snapshot of the iterator is captured, and then a new array is created from the contents of that snapshot. So there is O(n) memory overhead, in addition to the O(n) memory needed by the returned array.

        Parameters:
        iter - an iterator
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterator's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(), toArray(Iterator, Object[]), toArray(Iterable)

      • toArray

        public static <T> T[] toArray(Iterator<?> iter,
                              T[] array)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterator as an array of the given type. The given array is used if it is large enough. If it is too large, a null terminator will be written to the location after the end of the given iterable's contents. If it is too small, a new array with the same component type will be allocated and returned.
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterator
        array - an array
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(Object[]), toArray(Iterator), toArray(Iterable, Object[])

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        Returns:
        the given iterator, but with a generic type that is a super-type of the one given

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the given iterable, but with a generic type that is a super-type of the one given

      • push

        public static <E> Iterator<E> push(Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                                   E pushed)
        Pushes the given element onto the head of the given iterator. This returns a new iterator that first yields the pushed element and then yields the elements in the given iterator.

        If an attempt is made to remove the first element (the newly pushed element) via the iterator's remove method then an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown. Removal of other elements will delegate to the underlying iterator.

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        pushed - the element to push to the head of the iterator
        Returns:
        a new iterator, with the given element pushed in front

      • push

        public static <E> Iterator<E> push(Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                                   E pushed,
                                   Runnable onRemove)
        Pushes the given element onto the head of the given iterator. This returns a new iterator that first yields the pushed element and then yields the elements in the given iterator.

        If an attempt is made to remove the first element (the newly pushed element) via the iterator's remove method then the given removal handler is invoked.

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        pushed - the element to push to the head of the iterator
        onRemove - a removal handler
        Returns:
        a new iterator, with the given element pushed in front

      • push

        @SafeVarargs
public static <E> Iterator<E> push(Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                                                E... pushed)
        Pushes the given elements onto the head of the given iterator. This returns a new iterator that first yields the pushed elements, in the given order, and then yields the elements in the given iterator.

        Attempts to remove the pushed elements, using the returned iterator's remove method, will throw UnsupportedOperationExceptions.

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        pushed - the elements to push to the head of the iterator; the first element is emitted by the returned iterator first, and then the next and so on
        Returns:
        a new iterator, with the given elements pushed in front
        See Also:
        push(Iterator, Iterable)

      • push

        public static <E> Iterator<E> push(Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                                   Iterable<E> pushed)
        Pushes the given elements onto the head of the given iterator. This returns a new iterator that first yields the pushed elements, in the order they are emitted during iteration, and then yields the elements in the given iterator.

        Attempts to remove the pushed elements, using the returned iterator's remove method, will remove them from the given iterable if possible by delegating to an iterator over the given pushed elements.

        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        pushed - the elements to push to the head of the iterator
        Returns:
        a new iterator, with the given elements pushed in front
        See Also:
        push(Iterator, Object...)

      • concat

        @SafeVarargs
public static <E> Iterator<E> concat(Iterator<? extends E>... iterators)
        Concatenates all of the given iterators into one. Iteration order will yield all elements in the first given iterator, and then the next and so on.

        Attempts to remove the elements using Iterator.remove() will remove them from the underlying iterator that emitted them.

        Parameters:
        iterators - an array of iterators
        Returns:
        a view of the array of iterators as a single iterators with all elements concatenated into a new sequence
        See Also:
        concat(Iterable)

      • concat

        public static <E> Iterator<E> concat(Iterable<Iterator<? extends E>> iterators)
        Concatenates all of the given iterators into one. Iteration order will yield all elements in the first given iterator, and then the next and so on.

        Attempts to remove the elements using Iterator.remove() will remove them from the underlying iterator that emitted them.

        Parameters:
        iterators - a sequence of iterators
        Returns:
        a view of the array of iterators as a single iterators with all elements concatenated into a new sequence
        See Also:
        concat(Iterator...)

      • concatIterables

        @SafeVarargs
public static <E> Iterable<E> concatIterables(Iterable<? extends E>... iterables)

      • concatIterables

        public static <E> Iterable<E> concatIterables(Iterable<Iterable<? extends E>> iterables)

      • upToN

        public static <E> Iterable<E> upToN(Iterable<E> iterable,
                                    int n)
        Returns a view of the first n elements of the given iterable. This iterable will yield elements from the given iterable until either the underlying iterable is exhausted or it has yielded the given number of elements.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        n - the maximum number of elements to yield
        Returns:
        an iterable that contains up to the first n elements of the given iterable
        See Also:
        upToN(Iterator, int)

      • upToN

        public static <E> Iterator<E> upToN(Iterator<E> iterator,
                                    int n)
        Returns a view of the first n elements of the given iterator. This iterator will yield elements from the given iterator until either the underlying iterator is exhausted or it has yielded the given number of elements.
        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        n - the maximum number of elements to yield
        Returns:
        an iterator that yields up to the first n elements of the given iterator
        See Also:
        upToN(Iterable, int)

      • flatMap

        public static <T,U> Iterator<U> flatMap(Iterator<T> iterator,
                                        Function<? super T,? extends Iterator<? extends U>> fn)
        Expands the given sequence using the given function. Each element in the given iterator is transformed into another sequence via the function. The resulting iterator concatenates all such resulting sequences.
        Parameters:
        iterator - an iterator
        fn - a function that expands each element into another sequence
        Returns:
        an iterator that the results of expanding each element
